title: Protocol for the isolation of mouse muscle stem cells using fluorescence-activated cell sorting
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of muscle digestion media
Timing: ∼10 min
      Enzymatic digestion of skeletal muscle is the essential first step. Ensure
      that Digest mix 1 is stored on ice prior to step 8.
    
        Prepare Digest 1 mix containing 0.2% Collagenase Type II (285 U/mg)
        dissolved in DMEM.
        
            Pass digest 1 solution through a filtered tissue culture bottle
            (Thermo Scientific, Cat# 157-0020) and keep on ice until step 8.
          
Extraction of mice skeletal muscle
Timing: ∼10–15 min per mouse
    
      This step details our strategy for extracting skeletal muscle from mice.
      Maximizing your skeletal muscle amount at the beginning will increase your
      yield of FACS isolated muscle stem cells at the end of the protocol.
    
        Prepare a de-contaminated dissection field on a benchtop by cleaning it
        with 70% ethanol.
      
        Transfer 20 mL of Digest 1 mix into a tube labeled Digest 1. Prepare a
        tube for each replicate mouse. Keep the tubes on ice.
      
        Euthanize mice according to your institution’s approved IACUC protocol.
      
        Spray down mouse with 70% ethanol, remove skin, and extract hindlimb (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A and 1B), triceps (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C), and abdominal (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D) skeletal muscles and place muscles in tube containing ice-cold
        Digest 1 mix.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3060-Fig1.jpg
              Figure 1. Extraction of hindlimb, triceps, and abdominal skeletal
              muscles from adult mice
            
Mouse skeletal muscle dissection.
              (A) Create a transverse incision along the waist and peel away
              skin and underlying fascia to access (B) hindlimb, (C) forelimb,
              and (D) abdominal skeletal muscles.
            
        Seal the tube containing Digest 1 and muscle with parafilm. Keep the
        tube on ice until step 8.
      
        Repeat steps 4–6 for each additional replicate mouse. Disinfect
        dissection tools and dissection platform between each mouse with 70%
        ethanol to avoid cross-contamination of samples.
      
Critical: It may be necessary to wash

skeletal muscle in a petri dish filled with PBS prior to step 6 to remove
      excess blood from the dissection.
    
      Enzymatic and mechanical dissociation of skeletal muscle to release
      mono-nuclear cells associated with skeletal muscle
    
Timing: ∼2 h for 1 mouse. Add 15–30 min
      for each additional mouse.
    
      Enzymatic digestion of skeletal muscle loosens the connections between
      bulk skeletal muscle fibers and mechanical dissociation releases single
      fibers. Gravitational sedimentation is performed to separate interstitial
      cells from single fibers containing MuSCs. Lastly, a second digestion step
      releases MuSCs from underneath the basal lamina of myofibers prior to
      FACS.
    
        Disinfect tubes with 70% ethanol and incubate tube(s) containing Digest
        1 and muscle at 37°C in a shaking (55 RPM) water bath for 90 min.
        
            Use weighted rings to keep 50 mL conical tubes secured to the bottom
            of the shaking bath.
          
        Prepare the following during Digest 1 incubation:
        
            Prepare glass tips (1 per mouse) for trituration by safely breaking
            off the thin barrel of a glass Pasteur pipet. Attach a latex bulb
            over the broken opening of the pipet (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
            
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3060-Fig2.jpg
                  Figure 2. Preparing glass Pasteur pipets for trituration
                
                  Safely cut Pasteur pipets at the dotted line and place a bulb
                  on the cut end of the pipet. We note that the users can
                  fire-polish the uncut end to create different size diameters
                  which may help with the mincing step.
                
Label 2 × 50 mL conical tubes per mouse.
            Prepare 5 mL of Digest 1 stop solution (20% FBS or DBS in F10) for
            each mouse.
          
        After Digest 1 incubation is complete, remove floating debris from
        Digest 1 tubes by carefully decanting each tube.
      
        Inactivate Digest 1 by adding 5 mL of Digest 1 stop solution to each
        tube.
      
Gently swirl the tube(s) to mix.

Carefully add 25 mL of PBS to each Digest 1 tube by pipetting to the
        wall of the tube.
        
            Slowly decant the supernatant, leaving only a little liquid covering
            the muscle.
          
        Repeat Step 13 two more times to remove residual Digest 1 Mix.
        
The supernatant should become clearer with each wash.
        After the third wash, pour all muscles into a petri dish that contains
        25 mL of PBS to start the trituration process (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3060-Fig3.jpg
              Figure 3. Mechanical dissociation of skeletal muscle to release
              single fibers
            
              Trituration of skeletal muscle releases myofibers. (A) Digested
              muscle is poured into a dish containing PBS and subsequently
              triturated.
            
              (B) A gentle round of trituration releases myofibers, with (C) a
              second round of trituration liberating additional myofibers from
              muscle.
            
              (D) If optimally performed, the third round of trituration results
              in muscles appearing paler and less opaque because of releasing
              most of the myofibers. In a subsequent digestion step, MuSCs can
              be released from the basal lamina of myofibers.
            
        Gently triturate the largest muscles (i.e., quadriceps and
        gastrocnemius) first, mincing several times for each muscle. See
        Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1] for an example of optimal
        trituration cadence and technique (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
        
            During the first round of trituration, the PBS solution should turn
            very cloudy from myofibers that are released into solution (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
          
        Collect all the solution (including released myofibers which contain
        MuSCs under their basal lamina) from the petri dish using a serological
        pipet. Split the collected solution equally into two 50 mL collection
        tubes for each mouse.
      
Note: After each successive round of
      trituration, there will be a gradual decline in the cloudiness of the
      supernatant in the petri dish.
    
        Add 25 mL of PBS into the petri dish for a second round of mincing.

Triturate smaller muscles (i.e., triceps, tibialis anterior, and
        abdominal muscles). Repeat step 16 (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
      
        Add 25 mL of PBS into each dish for a third round of mincing. Triturate
        all muscles. Repeat step 16. (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
      
        Fill up each sedimentation collection tube to 50 mL with PBS. Place all
        tubes upright in a stationary 37°C incubator for 25 min for
        gravitational sedimentation to occur.
      
Critical: The sedimentation step
      separates interstitial cells (low density) from myofibers (high density).
      Tubes should be minimally perturbed through steps 19–26. Rough handling at
      this stage will lead to myofibers being resuspended in the supernatant,
      which will decrease the final MuSC yield.
    
        During the first sedimentation step, label one 50 mL conical tube per
        mouse and keep the tube on ice.
        
            Collect the interstitial cells (ICs) (i.e., supernatant in
            collection tubes), including MuSCs liberated early from myofibers
            after Digest 1, and use them for single-color and
            fluorescent-minus-one (FMOs) controls.
          
        After the first sedimentation step is complete, carefully remove the
        collection tubes from the incubator.
        
            Collect 15 mL of supernatant from each tube and deposit the solution
            into the ICs tube(s) and leave on ice.
          
            Subsequently, add 15 mL of fresh PBS to each sedimentation tube by
            pipetting onto the side of the wall for each tube. Be careful to not
            disturb the myofiber sediment at the bottom of the tube.
          
        Incubate the collection tubes for 15 min at 37°C (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3060-Fig4.jpg
              Figure 4. Gravitational sedimentation of myofibers
            
Phases of gravitational sedimentation.
              (A) Interstitial cells (ICs) are dispersed in the supernatant
              after the first round of sedimentation.
            
              (B) By the second round, the supernatant becomes clearer, as IC
              cells are progressively depleted from the supernatant.
            
              (C) By the third round of gravitational sedimentation, the
              supernatant is visibly clear and myofibers are enriched at the

bottom of the tube.
            
        During the second sedimentation step, prepare Digest 2 mix (0.0125%
        Collagenase Type II (285 U/mg)/0.05% Dispase II (1.81 U/mg) in F10).
        Keep Digest 2 mix at 37°C until needed in step 27.
        
            Filter Digest 2 mix through a filtered tissue culture bottle (Thermo
            Scientific, Cat# 157-0020).
          
        Carefully remove 20 mL of supernatant from each sedimentation tube.
        Gently add 20 mL of fresh PBS into the tube without disturbing sediment
        at the bottom of the tube.
      
        Incubate the sedimentation tubes for 10 min at 37°C (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
      
        Gently remove supernatant to the 15 mL mark for each tube and
        immediately add 15 mL of pre-warmed Digest 2 mix to each tube.
      
        Seal each tube with parafilm and incubate tubes at 37°C in a shaking (55
        RPM) water bath for 30 min.
      
Critical: Do not digest myofibers for
      longer than 30 minutes. Over-digestion leads to excessive cleavage of cell
      surface markers that are necessary for FACS-based isolation of MuSCs.
      Thus, longer times in Digest 2 may decrease MuSC yield during
      FACS-isolation.
    
        After 30 min, immediately inactivate Digest II by adding 2 mL of Fetal
        Bovine Serum or Donor Bovine Serum (DBS) to each tube and gently swirl
        the tube to mix.
      
        Release MuSCs from digested myofibers by quickly pipetting the digested
        fibers up and down 10x times with a 25 mL serological pipet.
      
        Centrifuge tubes for 15 s (40 × g) at 4°C to sediment leftover
        debris.
      
        Collect the supernatant from each tube and filter it through a 70 μm
        cell strainer placed in a new 50 mL tube labeled according to each mouse
        replicate.
      
        Centrifuge (400 × g) each tube for 5 min at 4°C.
        
            Remove supernatant and resuspend mono-nuclear cells in 0.5–1 mL of
            SM to count cells on a hemocytometer.

Count ICs for the single-color/Fluorescent minus one (FMO) control
            samples at this step.
          
Note: If too many red blood cells are seen
      in the pellet, perform an Ammonium Chloride Potassium (ACK lysis)
      treatment to lyse them according to the manufacturer’s protocol
      https://www.thermofisher.com/us/en/home/references/gibco-cell-culture-basics/cell-culture-protocols/red-blood-cell-lysis-using-ack-lysing-buffer.html[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/us/en/home/references/gibco-cell-culture-basics/cell-culture-protocols/red-blood-cell-lysis-using-ack-lysing-buffer.html].
    
        Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
      
          Methods video S1. Trituration of mouse skeletal muscle, related to
          step 16
        
          Gently triturate large hindlimb muscles first, mincing several times
          for each muscle. Optimal trituration cadence and technique aids the
          release of muscle fibers from muscle tissue.
        
      Antibody staining of mono-nuclear cells associated with skeletal muscle
    
Timing: ∼2–2.5 h, depending on the
      number of mice
    
      In this step you will use antibody staining to negatively exclude
      fibro-adipogenic progenitors (FAPS), endothelial cells, and blood cells
      while enriching for PAX7-positive MuSCs. In this protocol, we use positive
      selection cell surface markers, CD29 (β1 Integrin) and CXCR4, which has
      previously been shown to overlap with Vcam1 and Alpha-7 integrin/CD34 on
      quiescent or early activated MuSCs.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
        Label 5 mL FACS tubes for unstained, single-color controls (SSC), and
        fluorescence-minus-one (FMO) controls listed below:
        
Unstained.
SSC-Propidium Iodine (PI).
SSC-Calcein Blue (CB).
SSC-APC.
SSC-APC-Cy7.
SSC-PE-Cy7.
FMO-APC.
FMO-APC-Cy7.
FMO-PE-Cy7.
Label FACS tubes for each experimental sample.
Critical: Keep a ratio of 1e6
      cells per 100 μL of SM. We have carefully titrated our antibodies to work
      optimally at this ratio.
    
        Transfer 4e6 cells to their respective FACS tubes in a final
        volume of 400 μL of SM.
      
        Stain cells in control and experimental samples with fluorescently
        conjugated antibodies according to our staining scheme to detect target
        antigens (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
        table:files/protocols_protocol_3060_5.csv
          Primary Antibody Scheme of FACS Controls and Experimental Samples. ‘+’
          indicates the addition of antibody; SCC = Single Color Control; FMO =
          Fluorescence Minus One.
        
            Shield stained cells from light and keep tubes partially immersed in

ice to prevent cells from internalizing antibodies.
          
Incubate stained cells on ice for 30 min.
        Wash stained cells by adding 3 mL of SM to each FACS tube. Centrifuge
        (360 × g) tubes for 5 min at 4°C. Decant the supernatant and
        resuspend in 400 μL of SM.
      
        Incubate stained cells with PE-Cy7 Streptavidin antibody for 20 min and
        keep on ice.
      
        Wash stained cells by adding 3 mL of SM to each tube. Centrifuge (360
        × g) for 5 min at 4°C. Remove the supernatant and repeat the wash
        step one additional time, for 2 washes in total.
      
        Filter cells through a 40 μm cell strainer and into freshly labeled FACS
        tubes to prepare for FACS analysis. Keep stained cells in tubes immersed
        on ice.
      
        15 min prior to FACS analysis, filter cells through a 40 μm cell
        strainer.
      
        Add PI and Calcein Blue to corresponding tubes 15 min prior to FACS (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
      
Flow cytometry and FACS-based purification of MuSCs
Timing: ∼2–4 h, depending on the number
      of mice
    
      Using the appropriate single color and fluorescent-minus-one (FMO)
      controls, we discuss the key steps and gating strategy for FACS-purifying
      MuSCs (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3060-Fig5.jpg
          Figure 5. FACS gating plots of β1-integrin and CXCR4+ MuSCs
        
FACS gating strategy for sorting prospective MuSCs.
(A) Debris are removed.
(B) Single cells are isolated.
(C) PI-negative and Calcein blue-positive cells (live) are gated.
          (D) Muscle-resident FAPs (Sca1+), blood cells
          (CD45+, CD11b+, TER119+) and
          endothelial cells (CD31+) are excluded by negative
          selection markers.
        
          (E) MuSCs are identified as double-positive for β1-integrin
          and CXCR4.
        
        Set up the BD FACS Aria III cytometer as specified by the manufacturer.
        
Use a 70 μm nozzle with a flow rate of 2.0–4.0.
        Run your unstained control to set the background voltage for each
        channel.

Run each single-color control (SCC) sample and set voltage for positive
        cells and record events for the top 25% of expressing events for
        fluorophore compensations.
      
        After compensation for all channels, run FMO samples to assist with
        drawing negative gates for APC (CD45, CD11b, TER119, SCA1, CD31) and
        positive gates for APC-Cy7 (β1 Integrin) and PE-Cy7 (CXCR4) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
      
        Sort CD45-; Cd11b-; TER119-;
        SCA1-; CD31-; β1 Integrin+; CXCR4+
        MuSCs for further analysis.
        
            Freshly sorted MuSCs will appear as small, rounded cells that divide
            over the next 48–72 h as they exit quiescence.
          
Note: This protocol can easily be used
      with other positive enriching cell surface markers including Vcam1 and
      α7-Integrin/CD34, which we previously showed enriches for a largely
      overlapping PAX7-positive cell population when extracted from uninjured
      skeletal muscle.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
      Downstream ex vivo and in vivo analysis of sorted MuSCs
    
      In this section we discuss downstream applications including cell culture,
      immunofluorescence (IF), cell transduction, gene expression analysis, and
      transplantation of MuSCs.
    
        Culturing and Passaging MuSCs (Time: 30–60 min to passage).
        
            Pre-coat wells with coating media (See
            materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]) for
            24 h prior to FACS.
          
            Freshly isolated MuSCs can be sorted directly into pre-coated wells
            that contain GM.
            
                Supplement cultured MuSCs with daily addition of 5 ng/mL bFGF
                and incubate at 37°C with 5% CO2.
              
                Fresh MuSCs FACS-isolated from uninjured muscle will start to
                divide in 48–72 h.
              
            After 3 days of culturing, we remove ½ the volume of GM and replaced
            ½ the volume with fresh GM. We repeat this 3 times.
            
Critical: Do not remove media
              completely within the first few days since MuSCs have low
              adherence in the first 48 hours after FACS isolation.
            
            After 5 days of culturing, we passage the progeny of MuSCs (i.e.,
            myoblasts) onto new tissue culture plates by performing the
            following:

Detach MuSCs from plates by removing ½ the volume of GM and
                replacing it with an equal volume of warmed 5 mM EDTA and
                incubate plates for 20 min at 37°C.
              
                Confirm that >90% of cells have been detached from the plate
                under a microscope and then use a pipet to wash the bottom of
                each plate to gently push cells into a cell suspension.
              
                Transfer the cell suspension to a labeled 15 mL conical tube and
                centrifuge (360 × g) for 5 min at 4°C.
              
                Resuspend the resulting pellet in GM to count cells in the
                suspension.
              
                Seed cells at the appropriate density and continue culturing in
                GM.
              
                Supplement with daily additions of bFGF.
                
Note: We passage our cell
                  cultures at 75%–80% confluent to prevent terminal
                  differentiation. Re-fresh the media every 2–3 days, as in step
                  50c.
                
        Differentiating MuSC-derived myoblasts into myotubes in culture (Time:
        48–72 h).
        
            Seed MuSCs into pre-coated wells containing differentiation media
            (DM).
            
                We perform differentiation assays in 96-well plates and thus
                seed ∼8,000 cells into 96-wells containing DM and without bFGF.
              
            To differentiate myoblasts into fully formed myotubes, culture the
            cells in DM for ∼48–72 h.
          
        Total RNA Extraction from freshly sorted MuSCs for analyzing Gene
        Expression (Time: 15–30 min).
        
            Prepare an RNase-free environment on the lab bench and label 1.5 mL
            microcentrifuge tubes.
          
            Aliquot 500 μL of TRIzol LS (Invitrogen, Cat #10296010) into each
            tube prior to going to the FACS facility.
          
            Sort 1–50,000 MuSCs into 500 μL of TRIzol LS, immediately vortex
            tube(s), and then add 250 μL of TRIzol LS to bring volume to 750 μL.
          
Incubate tubes with RNA/TRIzol for 5 min at 25°C.
Store RNA in TRIzol LS at ‒80°C for up to 2–3 months.
            Perform extraction of RNA according to the manufacturer’s protocol
            (TRIzol LS)
            https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Ftrizol_ls_reagent.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.com/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Ftrizol_ls_reagent.pdf].

Immunofluorescence staining of fixed MuSCs (Time: 2 Days).
        
            Remove ½ the volume of GM from each well. Add back the same volume
            with 8% paraformaldehyde (PFA) (4% PFA final concentration) and
            incubate MuSCs at RT for 20 min.
          
            Stop fixation by washing cells with Phosphate Buffered Saline (PBS)
            with 0.1% Tween 20 (PBST) 3 times for 5 min.
          
Permeabilize cells with 0.3% Triton-X for 20 min at 25°C.
Wash cells with PBST 3 times for 5 min.
            Add blocking buffer (5% Normal Goat Serum, 3% BSA, 0.3% Triton-X in
            PBS) for 2 h at RT.
          
            Without washing, add primary antibody in blocking buffer to each
            well and incubate for ∼12 h at 4°C.
          
            Remove primary antibody solution and wash cells 4 times for 15 min
            with PBST at 25°C.
          
            Add secondary antibody in blocking buffer to wells and incubate for
            1 h at 25°C.
          
            Remove the secondary antibody from solution by washing cells with
            PBST 4 times for 15 min at 25°C.
          
            Add Hoechst stain (1 μg/mL Hoechst in PBS) to cells and incubate for
            15 min at 25°C. Alternatively, you can add Hoechst into the third
            wash in step 53i.
          
            Remove Hoechst stain solution and wash cells with PBST for 5 min.
          
        Transduction of MuSCs with Lentivirus (Time: 2.5 h for transduction).
        
            We titrate our virus to determine the optimal density that gives
            maximal transduction and minimal toxicity (anywhere from
            1:100-1:500) as determined by a GFP fluorescence and/or antibiotic
            selection.
          
            We make virus in 293T cells, concentrate virus with PEG-it viral
            precipitation reagent (System Biosciences, Cat# LV810A-1), and then
            resuspend in GM supplemented with 25 mM HEPES.
          
            Sort 3,000 MuSCs into coated wells of a 96 well plate containing
            200 μL of GM.
          
            In a viral-only Biohazard class II biosafety cabinet, prepare

diluted lentiviral stock by diluting lentivirus solution with
            8 μg/mL Polybrene (Sigma-Aldrich, Cat. TR-1003-G) at the empirically
            tested viral ratio.
          
            Remove ½ the volume of GM from each well and add back the same
            volume with diluted viral media to get the desired ratio. Carefully,
            pipet each well 5x times with a P200 pipet and incubate the plate
            for 15 min at 37°C.
          
            Quickly parafilm plates shut to prevent spilling of virus while
            spinning cells and centrifuge (930 × g) plates for 90 min at
            32°C.
          
            Wash out virus by removing ½ volume (100 μL) and replacing ½ volume
            (100 μL) with fresh GM 8 times.
          
            After the last wash, add bFGF to a final concentration of 5 ng/mL
            before returning to 37°C to each well daily.
          
Note: Depending on your viral construct
      (i.e., constitutive versus inducible) your protein of interest can be
      expressed within 24–48 h.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
        Transplantation of MuSCs into pre-injured mice (Time: 2 h).
        
            Following your institution’s IACUC protocol, 24 h prior to
            transplantation, inject a chemical agent into the Tibialis Anterior
            (TA) muscle of mice to induce injury.
            
Note: We readily use 25 μL of
              10 μM cardiotoxin (CTX) or 50 μL of 1.2% Barium Chloride
              (BaCl2).
            
            Sort MuSCs at desired numbers into 500 μL of staining media (SM) in
            Eppendorf tubes and keep on ice.
          
            Pellet cells by spinning them down at 400 × g for 5 min,
            remove supernatant, and resuspend cells in ∼25 μL of saline.
            
Note: When transplanting a low
              number of cells (less than 10K) you will likely not see a pellet.
            
            To prevent cells from sticking to the plastic walls of the syringe,
            pre-coat the BD Biosciences syringe with FBS.
          
            Using a 31-gauge insulin syringe, take in 25 μL of cells (in saline)
            into the syringe.

Inject the needle at a 25° angle for a few cm, then reduce angle to
            0° (parallel with the TA) for a few more cm such that the tip of the
            needle is the mid belly of the TA.
          
            Inject the entire volume and slowly remove the needle from the TA
            and dispose in a sharps bin.
            
Critical: Removing the needle
              too quickly leads to leakage of cell volume from TA, and thus,
              compromising your transplantation experiment.
